netsquid.components.qdetector

Defines two quantum detectors used to model a physical entity in the network capable of measuring single or multiple (entangled) qubits.

class netsquid.components.qdetector.QuantumDetector(name, num_input_ports=1, num_output_ports=1, observable=ops.Z, meas_operators=None, system_delay=0., dead_time=0., models=None, output_meta=None, error_on_fail=False, properties=None)

Bases: Component

This component models hardware that measures qubits.

This component can model a single detector, or a detector system composed of arbitrary hardware with synchronized detectors performing the measurement. The system is triggered when a qubit enters the detector system on a port. The classical outcome(s) of the measurement are emitted via the output ports. After the measurement the detector may enter a deadtime in which the detector can’t be triggered.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – Name of the QuantumDetector

  • num_input_ports (int, optional) – Number of ports available for qubit input. Must be at least one. Default 1.

  • num_output_ports (int, optional) – Number of ports available for measurement outcome output. Must be at least one. Default 1.

  • observable (Operator, optional) – Operator to use for single qubit projective measurements if no measurement operators are given. Every qubit is measured individually in this setting. Default Z observable.

  • meas_operators (list or tuple of Operator or None, optional) – Operators used for general single or multi qubit measurements. If the number of qubits which has arrived doesn’t match the POVM the measurement will fail. This means a fail event will be scheduled and the returned message is an empty list. If set overrides the observable, otherwise ignored.

  • system_delay (float, optional) – Time between arrival of the qubit in the system and the actual measurement. During this time window other arriving qubits become part of the measurement. The effect of the system during this time window should be applied during pre-processing.

  • dead_time (float, optional) – Time after the measurement in which the detectors can’t be triggered. It is possible for qubits to propagate through the system during the dead time. Qubits that would arrive at the detectors during their dead_time are discarded when they enter the system.

  • models (dict or None, optional) – Models associated with this component. See the Models section to see which (key, Model) pair it recognizes.

  • output_meta (dict or None, optional) – Metadata which is added to the output message

  • error_on_fail (bool, optional) – Flag to indicate if an error is raised when a measurement has failed.

  • properties (dict or None, optional) – Additional properties for this component. See the Properties section to see defined properties.

Properties:

  • system_delay (float) – Time between arrival of the qubit in the system and the actual measurement. During this time window other arriving qubits become part of the measurement. The effect of the system during this time window should be applied during pre-processing.

  • dead_time (float) – Time after the measurement in which the detectors can’t be triggered. It is possible for qubits to propagate through the system during the dead time. Qubits that would arrive at the detectors during their dead_time are discarded when they enter the system.

Ports:

  • qin{0..(N-1)} – Input ports for qubits

  • cout{0..(N-1)} – Output ports for the measurement result

Models:

  • qin{0..(N-1)}_noise_model (QuantumErrorModel) – Model applied to qubits during preprocessing on the port identified with the index.

  • cout{0..(N-1)}_noise_model (ClassicalErrorModel) – Model applied to the measurement results during postprocessing on the port identified with the number.

  • cout{0..(N-1)}_delay_model (DelayModel) – Delay model used to model jitter effects on the measurement outcomes.

Raises:

  • ValueError – If the number of input/output ports is not an integer. If the number of input/output ports is below 1.

  • TypeError – If the properties parameter is not of type dict. If the measurement operators are not a list or tuple. If the measurement operators or observable are not of class Operator. If the output_meta is not of type dict.

Notes

Qubits are measured in a specific order: From port 0 to N, and each port in order of arrival. This order is also important for the POVM measurement.

Dark counts and after pulsing can be modelled using the error models.

Examples

Import useful modules

>>> import netsquid as ns
>>> from netsquid.components.qdetector import QuantumDetector
>>> from netsquid.components.component import Message
>>> from netsquid.examples.simple_link import create_meas_ops

Create a single qubit detector.

>>> ns.sim_reset()
>>> detector = QuantumDetector('single_detector')
>>> detector.ports['cout0'].bind_output_handler(lambda msg: print(msg))
>>> q1 = ns.qubits.create_qubits(1)
>>> detector.ports['qin0'].tx_input(Message(q1))
>>> stats = ns.sim_run()
Message(items=[0])

Create a single qubit detector with 5 ns dead time.

>>> ns.sim_reset()
>>> detector = QuantumDetector('deadtime_detector', dead_time=5)
>>> detector.ports['cout0'].bind_output_handler(lambda msg: print(msg))
>>> q1, q2, q3 = ns.qubits.create_qubits(3)
>>> detector.ports['qin0'].tx_input(Message([q1]))
>>> stats = ns.sim_run(duration=4)
Message(items=[0])
>>> detector.ports['qin0'].tx_input(Message([q2]))  # Still in dead time, so no measurement occurs
>>> stats = ns.sim_run(end_time=6)

>>> detector.ports['qin0'].tx_input(Message([q3]))
>>> stats = ns.sim_run()
Message(items=[0])
>>> ns.sim_time()
11.0

Create a single detector system with a 10 ns system delay and 15 ns dead time. This means the triggering qubit takes 10 ns to propagate through the system, before it is measured at the detectors. Qubits that arrive during these 10 ns are assumed to arrive at the detector at the same time instant as the triggering qubit. Between 10 ns and 25 ns the detectors are in dead time, thus qubits arriving between 10 and 15 ns are immediately discarded. Qubits arriving after the 15 ns can be measured as normal, because after the system delay the dead time of the detectors would have passed.

>>> ns.sim_reset()
>>> detector = QuantumDetector('system_detector', system_delay=10, dead_time=15)
>>> detector.ports['cout0'].bind_output_handler(lambda msg: print(msg))
>>> q1, q2, q3, q4 = ns.qubits.create_qubits(4)
>>> detector.ports['qin0'].tx_input(Message([q1]))
>>> stats = ns.sim_run(end_time=10)
>>> detector.ports['qin0'].tx_input(Message([q2]))
>>> stats = ns.sim_run(end_time=13)  # We measure the two qubits
Message(items=[0, 0])
>>> detector.ports['qin0'].tx_input(Message([q3]))
>>> stats = ns.sim_run(end_time=16)  # The qubit is discarded

>>> detector.ports['qin0'].tx_input(Message([q4]))
>>> stats = ns.sim_run()
Message(items=[0])
>>> ns.sim_time()  # The system can accept qubits after 25-10=15 ns again
31.0

Create a quantum detector which performs a Bell measurement on two incoming qubits. These qubits must arrive at exactly the same moment in time.

>>> ns.sim_reset()
>>> ns.set_random_state(seed=44)
>>> detector = QuantumDetector('example_detector', num_input_ports=2,
...                            meas_operators=create_meas_ops())
>>> detector.ports['cout0'].bind_output_handler(lambda msg: print(msg))
>>> q1, q2 = ns.qubits.create_qubits(2)
>>> ns.qubits.operate(q1, ns.X)
>>> detector.ports['qin0'].tx_input(Message([q1]))
>>> detector.ports['qin1'].tx_input(Message([q2]))
>>> stats = ns.sim_run()
Message(items=[2])
add_ports(self, names)

Add ports to this component.

Added ports are accessible via ports.

Parameters:

names (list of str) – Names of ports.

Returns:

List of the ports with the given names.

Return type:

list of Port

Notes

If a port with this name already exists it is also returned in the list, but not overwritten.

add_property(self, name, value=None, mutable=True, value_type=None, value_constraints=None)

Add a property to this component.

Properties can be accessed and modified via the properties attribute.

If a property with this name already exists, an attempt will be made to set the new value.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – Name of the property.

  • value (Any) – Value of the property.

  • mutable (bool, optional) – Whether the property is mutable.

  • value_type (type, optional) – Type of this property

  • value_constraints (~netsquid.util.constrainedmap.ValueConstraint or list of ~netsquid.util.constrainedmap.ValueConstraint , optional) – constraint checks to verify if value is a valid value

add_subcomponent(self, component, name=None, forward_input=None, forward_output=None, add_ports=False)

Add a subcomponent to this component.

Subcomponents can be accessed using the subcomponents property.

If a component already exists with this name identifier it will be replaced.

Parameters:

  • component (Component) – Component to add.

  • name (str or None, optional) – Custom name identifier for component. If None (default), the name of the component being added is used. If a component using the same name already exists it is overridden.

  • forward_input (list of tuple of str or None, optional) – Names of ports to forward input from parent component to subcomponent. Each tuple in this list consist of two port names: The first port name is the port of the parentcomponent. The second port name is the port of the subcomponent.

  • forward_output (list of tuple of str or None, optional) – Names of ports to forward output from subcomponent to parent component. Each tuple in this list consist of two port names: The first port name is the port of the parentcomponent. The second port name is the port of the subcomponent.

  • add_ports (bool, optional) – If ports should be created if they do not yet exist. Default False

Raises:

ComponentHierarchyError – If the component to be added is already related to this component as a sub or super component at any depth. Or if the component is already a subcomponent of an other component.

Example

Instead of

>>> from netsquid.components import Component
...
>>> parent = Component("parent", port_names=["in_p", "out_p"])
>>> child = Component("child", port_names=["in_c", "out_c"])
>>> parent.add_subcomponent(child)
>>> parent.ports["in_p"].forward_input(child.ports["in_c"])
>>> child.ports["out_c"].forward_output(parent.ports["out_p"])

One can do

>>> parent = Component("parent", port_names=["in_p", "out_p"])
>>> child = Component("child", port_names=["in_c", "out_c"])
>>> parent.add_subcomponent(child,
...     forward_input=[("in_p", "in_c")],
...     forward_output=[("out_p", "out_c")])
finish(self)

Finish the detection round.

This method is called when the dead time ends.

Whether argument is a supercomponent of this component at any level.

in_dead_time

if the detector is in dead time.

Type:

inform(self, dict port_outcomes)

Put the outcomes on the output port.

Sends the outcomes with a delay based on the delaymodels.

Parameters:

port_outcomes (dict) – A dictionary with the port names as keys and a copy of the measurement outcomes as values

input_port_names

the names of the input ports.

Type:

tuple

is_triggered

if the detector is triggered.

Type:

bool

measure(self)

Perform a measurement on the received qubits.

Applies preprocessing to the qubits before the measurement, and applies postprocessing to the measured classical outcomes. After the measurement all qubits are discarded.

If an observable is specified, all qubits will be measured individually. Otherwise, if measurement operators are specified, all qubits will be measured with these operators. The qubits are ordered by port number and arrival time.

Raises:

QuantumDetectorError – If the number of qubits doesn’t match the measurement operators when error_on_fail is set.

models

the models associated with this component.

Models that a component can hold are strictly define at construction. To change the model use: models[name_model] = model().

Type:

ConstrainedMap

name

Name of component for identification and display purposes.

Type:

str

output_port_names

the names of the output ports.

Type:

tuple

ports

ports belonging to this component.

Type:

ConstrainedMap

postprocess_outputs(self, dict port_outcomes)

Processes the classical outcomes of the measurement before the message is send.

Applies a classical noise model if specified.

Override this method to change the preprocessing behaviour.

Parameters:

port_outcomes (dict) – A dictionary with the port names as keys and a copy of the measurement outcomes as values

preprocess_inputs(self)

Apply operations to qubits before they are measured.

Applies a quantum noise model per input port if specified. The model is given the elapsed time since the qubit arrived at the detector.

Override this method to change the preprocessing behaviour.

properties

the properties associated with this component.

Type:

ConstrainedMap

rem_subcomponent(self, name)

Remove a subcomponent from this component.

Outgoing port connections are disconnected to keep the hierarchy consistent; That means that any port connections to the parent or siblings are disconnected. Input ports to subcomponents remain.

Parameters:

name (str) – Name identifier for component.

remove(self)

Removes the entity from the simulation.

reset(self)

Reset the component.

Will reset all of its ports and (sub)components.

set_input_models(self, models)

Convenience method to set models for the input ports

Instead of providing each model separately via the models property, this method allows for providing a single model or a list of models.

Parameters:

models (QuantumErrorModel or list of them) – The model or models applied for each port.

Raises:

ValueError – If the model is not of type QuantumErrorModel

set_output_models(self, models)

Convenience method to set models for the output ports

Instead of providing each model separately via the models property, this method allows for providing a single model or a list of models.

Parameters:

models (ClassicalErrorModel or list of them) – The model or models applied for each port.

Raises:

ValueError – If the model is not of type ClassicalErrorModel

specify_model(self, name, model_type=None)

Specify the model types needed by this component.

Models that are not first specified cannot be set. To set a model do Component.models[name_model] = model.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – Key of item.

  • model_type (~netsquid.components.models.Model) – Type of model. If None, ~netsquid.components.models.Model base class is set.

Raises:

KeyError – If a model with name has already been specified.

subcomponents

Returns:

Subcomponents of this component.

Return type:

ConstrainedMap

supercomponent

parent component, if any.

Type:

Component or None

trigger(self)

Start the measurement process.

Schedules the measurement after the system delay. When called the detector should be ready to measure.

Raises:

QuantumDetectorError – If the detector is already triggered.

uid

returns a unique identifier for this entity in the simulation.

Each entity has a unique identifier in the simulation.

Type:

int

class netsquid.components.qdetector.GatedQuantumDetector(name, detection_window, num_input_ports=1, num_output_ports=1, observable=ops.Z, meas_operators=None, system_delay=0., dead_time=0., models=None, output_meta=None, error_on_fail=False, properties=None)

Bases: QuantumDetector

A quantum detector that can receive qubits during gated detection windows.

A detection window is triggered by a message on the trigger port. During this window the detector acts like a QuantumDetector. All qubits arriving at the detector outside the detection window are discarded immediately.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – Name of the QuantumDetector

  • detection_window (float) – The duration of activation after a trigger. Must be zero or positive.

  • num_input_ports (int, optional) – Number of ports available for qubit input. Must be at least one. Default 1.

  • num_output_ports (int, optional) – Number of ports available for measurement outcome output. Must be at least one. Default 1.

  • observable (Operator, optional) – Operator to use for single qubit projective measurements if no measurement operators are given. Every qubit is measured individually in this setting. Default Z obserable.

  • meas_operators (list of Operator or None, optional) – Operators used for general single or multi qubit measurements. If the number of qubits which has arrived doesn’t match the POVM the measurement will fail. This means a fail event will be scheduled and the returned message is an empty list. If set overrides the observable, otherwise ignored.

  • system_delay (float, optional) – Time between arrival of the qubit in the system and the actual measurement. During this time window other arriving qubits become part of the measurement. The effect of the system during this time window should be applied during pre-processing.

  • dead_time (float, optional) – Time after the measurement in which the detectors can’t be triggered. It is possible for qubits to propagate through the system during the dead time. Qubits that would arrive at the detectors during their dead_time are discarded when they enter the system.

  • models (dict or None, optional) – Models associated with this component. See the Models section to see which (key, Model) pair it recognizes.

  • output_meta (dict or None, optional) – Metadata which is added to the output message

  • error_on_fail (bool, optional) – Flag to indicate if an error is raised when a measurement has failed.

  • properties (dict or None, optional) – Additional properties for this component. See the Properties section to see defined properties.

Properties:

  • system_delay (float) – Time between arrival of the qubit in the system and the actual measurement. During this time window other arriving qubits become part of the measurement. The effect of the system during this time window should be applied during pre-processing.

  • dead_time (float) – Time after the measurement in which the detectors can’t be triggered. It is possible for qubits to propagate through the system during the dead time. Qubits that would arrive at the detectors during their dead_time are discarded when they enter the system.

  • detection_window (float) – The duration of the time window. Must be zero or positive.

Ports:

  • qin{0..(N-1)} – Input ports for qubits

  • cout{0..(N-1)} – Output ports for the measurement result

  • gate_trigger – Any message which arrives on this port triggers the time window.

Models:

  • qin{0..(N-1)}_noise_model (QuantumErrorModel) – Model applied to qubits during preprocessing on the port identified with the index.

  • cout{0..(N-1)}_noise_model (ClassicalErrorModel) – Model applied to the measurement results during postprocessing on the port identified with the number.

  • cout{0..(N-1)}_delay_model (DelayModel) – Delay model used to model jitter effects on the measurement outcomes.

Raises:

  • ValueError – If the number of input/output ports is not an integer. If the number of input/output ports is below 1.

  • TypeError – If the properties parameter is not of type dict. If the measurement operators or observable are not of class Operator. If the output_meta is not of type dict.

  • ValueError – If the time windows is negative.

Notes

The gate is applied on the whole system and not just the measurement devices, like the dead time is. To model a system where the gate affects the measurement devices only, one could use a channel-like component to model the system and connect it to the detector manually.

Examples

To specify a detector that measures continuously during the time window, use a system delay of 0.

>>> import netsquid as ns
>>> from netsquid.components import Clock, GatedQuantumDetector, Message
...
>>> ns.sim_reset()
>>> test_detector = GatedQuantumDetector('test', detection_window=10,
...                                      num_input_ports=2)
>>> test_detector.ports['cout0'].bind_output_handler(lambda msg: print(msg.items))
>>> clock = Clock('external_clock', frequency=10) # The frequency is in Hz.
>>> clock.ports['cout'].connect(test_detector.ports['gate_trigger'])
>>> clock.start()
>>> # We need to get a trigger before we can start measuring
>>> stats = ns.sim_run(1)
>>> q1, q2 = ns.qubits.create_qubits(2)
>>> test_detector.ports['qin0'].tx_input(Message([q1]))
>>> test_detector.ports['qin1'].tx_input(Message([q2]))
>>> stats = ns.sim_run(2)
[0, 0]
>>> stats = ns.sim_run(11)
>>> # Time window is now over, we won't measure anything
>>> q3, q4 = ns.qubits.create_qubits(2)
>>> test_detector.ports['qin0'].tx_input(Message([q3]))
>>> test_detector.ports['qin1'].tx_input(Message([q4]))
>>> stats = ns.sim_run(1e8+1)
>>> # The detector has received the next trigger
>>> q5, q6 = ns.qubits.create_qubits(2)
>>> test_detector.ports['qin0'].tx_input(Message([q5]))
>>> test_detector.ports['qin1'].tx_input(Message([q6]))
>>> stats = ns.sim_run(1e8+2)
[0, 0]

To create a detector that always measures at the end of the time window, specify a system delay greater than or equal to the time window. Measurements scheduled after the time window are forced to occur at the end automatically.

>>> test_detector.properties['system_delay'] = 20
>>> stats = ns.sim_run(2e8+1)
>>> q5, q6 = ns.qubits.create_qubits(2)
>>> test_detector.ports['qin0'].tx_input(Message([q5]))
>>> stats = ns.sim_time(2e8+5)
>>> test_detector.ports['qin1'].tx_input(Message([q6]))
>>> stats = ns.sim_run(2e8+11)
[0, 0]
>>> stats = ns.sim_run(2e8+21)

add_subcomponent(self, component, name=None, forward_input=None, forward_output=None, add_ports=False)

Add a subcomponent to this component.

Subcomponents can be accessed using the subcomponents property.

If a component already exists with this name identifier it will be replaced.

Parameters:

  • component (Component) – Component to add.

  • name (str or None, optional) – Custom name identifier for component. If None (default), the name of the component being added is used. If a component using the same name already exists it is overridden.

  • forward_input (list of tuple of str or None, optional) – Names of ports to forward input from parent component to subcomponent. Each tuple in this list consist of two port names: The first port name is the port of the parentcomponent. The second port name is the port of the subcomponent.

  • forward_output (list of tuple of str or None, optional) – Names of ports to forward output from subcomponent to parent component. Each tuple in this list consist of two port names: The first port name is the port of the parentcomponent. The second port name is the port of the subcomponent.

  • add_ports (bool, optional) – If ports should be created if they do not yet exist. Default False

Raises:

ComponentHierarchyError – If the component to be added is already related to this component as a sub or super component at any depth. Or if the component is already a subcomponent of an other component.

Example

Instead of

>>> from netsquid.components import Component
...
>>> parent = Component("parent", port_names=["in_p", "out_p"])
>>> child = Component("child", port_names=["in_c", "out_c"])
>>> parent.add_subcomponent(child)
>>> parent.ports["in_p"].forward_input(child.ports["in_c"])
>>> child.ports["out_c"].forward_output(parent.ports["out_p"])

One can do

>>> parent = Component("parent", port_names=["in_p", "out_p"])
>>> child = Component("child", port_names=["in_c", "out_c"])
>>> parent.add_subcomponent(child,
...     forward_input=[("in_p", "in_c")],
...     forward_output=[("out_p", "out_c")])
finish(self)

Finish the detection round.

This method is called when the dead time ends.

has_subcomponent(self, component)

Whether argument is a subcomponent of this component at any level.

Returns:

True if component contained as a subcomponent at any level, otherwise False.

Return type:

bool

has_supercomponent(self, component)

Whether argument is a supercomponent of this component at any level.

in_dead_time

if the detector is in dead time.

Type:

bool

inform(self, dict port_outcomes)

Put the outcomes on the output port.

Sends the outcomes with a delay based on the delaymodels.

Parameters:

port_outcomes (dict) – A dictionary with the port names as keys and a copy of the measurement outcomes as values

input_port_names

the names of the input ports.

Type:

tuple

is_triggered

if the detector is triggered.

Type:

bool

measure(self)

Perform a measurement on the received qubits.

Applies preprocessing to the qubits before the measurement, and applies postprocessing to the measured classical outcomes. After the measurement all qubits are discarded.

If an observable is specified, all qubits will be measured individually. Otherwise, if measurement operators are specified, all qubits will be measured with these operators. The qubits are ordered by port number and arrival time.

Raises:

QuantumDetectorError – If the number of qubits doesn’t match the measurement operators when error_on_fail is set.

models

the models associated with this component.

Models that a component can hold are strictly define at construction. To change the model use: models[name_model] = model().

Type:

ConstrainedMap

name

Name of component for identification and display purposes.

Type:

str

output_port_names

the names of the output ports.

Type:

tuple

ports

ports belonging to this component.

Type:

ConstrainedMap

postprocess_outputs(self, dict port_outcomes)

Processes the classical outcomes of the measurement before the message is send.

Applies a classical noise model if specified.

Override this method to change the preprocessing behaviour.

Parameters:

port_outcomes (dict) – A dictionary with the port names as keys and a copy of the measurement outcomes as values

preprocess_inputs(self)

Apply operations to qubits before they are measured.

Applies a quantum noise model per input port if specified. The model is given the elapsed time since the qubit arrived at the detector.

Override this method to change the preprocessing behaviour.

properties

the properties associated with this component.

Type:

ConstrainedMap

rem_subcomponent(self, name)

Remove a subcomponent from this component.

Outgoing port connections are disconnected to keep the hierarchy consistent; That means that any port connections to the parent or siblings are disconnected. Input ports to subcomponents remain.

Parameters:

name (str) – Name identifier for component.

remove(self)

Removes the entity from the simulation.

reset(self)

Reset the component.

Will reset all of its ports and (sub)components.

set_input_models(self, models)

Convenience method to set models for the input ports

Instead of providing each model separately via the models property, this method allows for providing a single model or a list of models.

Parameters:

models (QuantumErrorModel or list of them) – The model or models applied for each port.

Raises:

ValueError – If the model is not of type QuantumErrorModel

set_output_models(self, models)

Convenience method to set models for the output ports

Instead of providing each model separately via the models property, this method allows for providing a single model or a list of models.

Parameters:

models (ClassicalErrorModel or list of them) – The model or models applied for each port.

Raises:

ValueError – If the model is not of type ClassicalErrorModel

specify_model(self, name, model_type=None)

Specify the model types needed by this component.

Models that are not first specified cannot be set. To set a model do Component.models[name_model] = model.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – Key of item.

  • model_type (~netsquid.components.models.Model) – Type of model. If None, ~netsquid.components.models.Model base class is set.

Raises:

KeyError – If a model with name has already been specified.

subcomponents

Return list of subcomponents of this component and their identifiers.

Returns:

Subcomponents of this component.

Return type:

ConstrainedMap

supercomponent

parent component, if any.

Type:

Component or None

trigger(self)

Start the measurement process.

Schedules the measurement after the system delay. When called the detector should be ready to measure.

Raises:

QuantumDetectorError – If the detector is already triggered.

uid

returns a unique identifier for this entity in the simulation.

Each entity has a unique identifier in the simulation.

Type:

int

exception netsquid.components.qdetector.QuantumDetectorError

Bases: Exception

with_traceback()

Exception.with_traceback(tb) – set self.__traceback__ to tb and return self.
